name: lingth
abstract: Introducing lingth, a simple line-length checker
words:
lingth is a “simple line-length checker” — it checks for long lines in a file.
    this can be useful for enforcing line lengths as part of coding guidelines, but the command has general applications (see
it should be straightforward to add to a git hook and enforce line length throughout a project.

is a pretty decent example of a small command-line app, written in php. it does all the flag-parsing, handling of multiple files, redirected input, etc. itself, but it’s still a very small codebase. this makes it good as a template for other work, or as an introduction to the language.
report any long lines (currently, longer than 80 chars) from all files ending ‘.php’.
get a list of words longer than 22 characters. (on my own system, there are exactly 22 words longer than 22 characters, all 23 or 24 characters long. “anthropomorphologically” is 23)
print ‘foo’, and nothing else, so long as ‘foo’ is longer than 2 characters (which it is!).
confirm the length of a single emoji character is just 1 (line length is in the output).
you can read more about lingth in
building a command line app in php
, an article i wrote explaning best practices for unix commands and how you can implement them.
